titleInfo.title: Stereocard of Memphis Exhibit, Negro Building, Atlanta Exposition, 1895

location.physicalLocation: Special Collections Division of the Nashville Public Library, 615 Church Street, Nashville, Tennessee, 37219

mods.abstract: A stereocard depicting the Memphis Exhibit for the Negro Building at the 1895 Atlanta Exposition. Pictured are four African Americans, two women and two men, in an interior setting. The words Shelby County Tennessee can be seen in the upper right corner of the frames. The Memphis Exhibit was organized by Julia Britton Hooks of Memphis, Tennessee. Julia Britton Hooks, an African American clubwoman known as the ""Angel of Beale Street,"" was born free in 1852 in Frankfort, Kentucky. Hooks was a charter member of the Memphis chapter of the NAACP and was the grandmother of the national director of the organization, Benjamin J. Hooks. Julia Hooks became a leader in African American cultural and educational affairs, and participant in the suffrage movement. A stereocard is depictions of the same image from two different angles, that when placed in a stereoscope make the image appear three dimensional.

titleInfo.title: Generations - African American Women's Early Activism in Tennessee
